00059 // Due to C++ preprocessor weirdness, we need double indirection to
00060 // concatenate two tokens when one of them is __LINE__.  Writing
00061 //
00062 //   foo ## __LINE__
00063 //
00064 // will result in the token foo__LINE__, instead of foo followed by
00065 // the current line number.  For more details, see
00066 // http://www.parashift.com/c++-faq-lite/misc-technical-issues.html#faq-39.6
00067 #define GTEST_CONCAT_TOKEN_(foo, bar) GTEST_CONCAT_TOKEN_IMPL_(foo, bar)
00068 #define GTEST_CONCAT_TOKEN_IMPL_(foo, bar) foo ## bar
00069 
00070 // Google Test defines the testing::Message class to allow construction of
00071 // test messages via the << operator.  The idea is that anything
00072 // streamable to std::ostream can be streamed to a testing::Message.
00073 // This allows a user to use his own types in Google Test assertions by
00074 // overloading the << operator.
00075 //
00076 // util/gtl/stl_logging-inl.h overloads << for STL containers.  These
00077 // overloads cannot be defined in the std namespace, as that will be
00078 // undefined behavior.  Therefore, they are defined in the global
00079 // namespace instead.
00080 //
00081 // C++'s symbol lookup rule (i.e. Koenig lookup) says that these
00082 // overloads are visible in either the std namespace or the global
00083 // namespace, but not other namespaces, including the testing
00084 // namespace which Google Test's Message class is in.
00085 //
00086 // To allow STL containers (and other types that has a << operator
00087 // defined in the global namespace) to be used in Google Test assertions,
00088 // testing::Message must access the custom << operator from the global
00089 // namespace.  Hence this helper function.
00090 //
00091 // Note: Jeffrey Yasskin suggested an alternative fix by "using
00092 // ::operator<<;" in the definition of Message's operator<<.  That fix
00093 // doesn't require a helper function, but unfortunately doesn't
00094 // compile with MSVC.
00095 template <typename T>
00096 inline void GTestStreamToHelper(std::ostream* os, const T& val) {
00097   *os << val;
00098 }
00099

00109 class UnitTest;                        // A collection of test cases.
00110 class UnitTestEventListenerInterface;  // Listens to Google Test events.
00111 class AssertionResult;                 // Result of an assertion.

00131 // A secret type that Google Test users don't know about.  It has no
00132 // definition on purpose.  Therefore it's impossible to create a
00133 // Secret object, which is what we want.
00134 class Secret;
00135 
00136 // Two overloaded helpers for checking at compile time whether an
00137 // expression is a null pointer literal (i.e. NULL or any 0-valued
00138 // compile-time integral constant).  Their return values have
00139 // different sizes, so we can use sizeof() to test which version is
00140 // picked by the compiler.  These helpers have no implementations, as
00141 // we only need their signatures.
00142 //
00143 // Given IsNullLiteralHelper(x), the compiler will pick the first
00144 // version if x can be implicitly converted to Secret*, and pick the
00145 // second version otherwise.  Since Secret is a secret and incomplete
00146 // type, the only expression a user can write that has type Secret* is
00147 // a null pointer literal.  Therefore, we know that x is a null
00148 // pointer literal if and only if the first version is picked by the
00149 // compiler.
00150 char IsNullLiteralHelper(Secret* p);
00151 char (&IsNullLiteralHelper(...))[2];  // NOLINT
00152 
00153 // A compile-time bool constant that is true if and only if x is a
00154 // null pointer literal (i.e. NULL or any 0-valued compile-time
00155 // integral constant).
00156 #ifdef GTEST_ELLIPSIS_NEEDS_COPY_
00157 // Passing non-POD classes through ellipsis (...) crashes the ARM
00158 // compiler.  The Nokia Symbian and the IBM XL C/C++ compiler try to
00159 // instantiate a copy constructor for objects passed through ellipsis
00160 // (...), failing for uncopyable objects.  Hence we define this to
00161 // false (and lose support for NULL detection).
00162 #define GTEST_IS_NULL_LITERAL_(x) false
00163 #else
00164 #define GTEST_IS_NULL_LITERAL_(x) \
00165     (sizeof(::testing::internal::IsNullLiteralHelper(x)) == 1)
00166 #endif  // GTEST_ELLIPSIS_NEEDS_COPY_

00168 // Appends the user-supplied message to the Google-Test-generated message.
00169 String AppendUserMessage(const String& gtest_msg,
00170                          const Message& user_msg);

00172 // A helper class for creating scoped traces in user programs.
00173 class ScopedTrace {
00174  public:
00175   // The c'tor pushes the given source file location and message onto
00176   // a trace stack maintained by Google Test.
00177   ScopedTrace(const char* file, int line, const Message& message);
00178 
00179   // The d'tor pops the info pushed by the c'tor.
00180   //
00181   // Note that the d'tor is not virtual in order to be efficient.
00182   // Don't inherit from ScopedTrace!
00183   ~ScopedTrace();
00184 
00185  private:
00186   GTEST_DISALLOW_COPY_AND_ASSIGN_(ScopedTrace);
00187 } GTEST_ATTRIBUTE_UNUSED_;  // A ScopedTrace object does its job in its
00188                             // c'tor and d'tor.  Therefore it doesn't
00189                             // need to be used otherwise.
00190 
00191 // Converts a streamable value to a String.  A NULL pointer is
00192 // converted to "(null)".  When the input value is a ::string,
00193 // ::std::string, ::wstring, or ::std::wstring object, each NUL
00194 // character in it is replaced with "\\0".
00195 // Declared here but defined in gtest.h, so that it has access
00196 // to the definition of the Message class, required by the ARM
00197 // compiler.
00198 template <typename T>
00199 String StreamableToString(const T& streamable);
00200 
00201 // Formats a value to be used in a failure message.
00202 
00203 #ifdef GTEST_NEEDS_IS_POINTER_
00204 
00205 // These are needed as the Nokia Symbian and IBM XL C/C++ compilers
00206 // cannot decide between const T& and const T* in a function template.
00207 // These compilers _can_ decide between class template specializations
00208 // for T and T*, so a tr1::type_traits-like is_pointer works, and we
00209 // can overload on that.
00210 
00211 // This overload makes sure that all pointers (including
00212 // those to char or wchar_t) are printed as raw pointers.
00213 template <typename T>
00214 inline String FormatValueForFailureMessage(internal::true_type dummy,
00215                                            T* pointer) {
00216   return StreamableToString(static_cast<const void*>(pointer));
00217 }
00218 
00219 template <typename T>
00220 inline String FormatValueForFailureMessage(internal::false_type dummy,
00221                                            const T& value) {
00222   return StreamableToString(value);
00223 }
00224 
00225 template <typename T>
00226 inline String FormatForFailureMessage(const T& value) {
00227   return FormatValueForFailureMessage(
00228       typename internal::is_pointer<T>::type(), value);
00229 }
00230 
00231 #else
00232 
00233 // These are needed as the above solution using is_pointer has the
00234 // limitation that T cannot be a type without external linkage, when
00235 // compiled using MSVC.
00236 
00237 template <typename T>
00238 inline String FormatForFailureMessage(const T& value) {
00239   return StreamableToString(value);
00240 }
00241 
00242 // This overload makes sure that all pointers (including
00243 // those to char or wchar_t) are printed as raw pointers.
00244 template <typename T>
00245 inline String FormatForFailureMessage(T* pointer) {
00246   return StreamableToString(static_cast<const void*>(pointer));
00247 }
00248 
00249 #endif  // GTEST_NEEDS_IS_POINTER_
00250 
00251 // These overloaded versions handle narrow and wide characters.
00252 String FormatForFailureMessage(char ch);
00253 String FormatForFailureMessage(wchar_t wchar);

00255 // When this operand is a const char* or char*, and the other operand
00256 // is a ::std::string or ::string, we print this operand as a C string
00257 // rather than a pointer.  We do the same for wide strings.
00258 
00259 // This internal macro is used to avoid duplicated code.
00260 #define GTEST_FORMAT_IMPL_(operand2_type, operand1_printer)\
00261 inline String FormatForComparisonFailureMessage(\
00262     operand2_type::value_type* str, const operand2_type& /*operand2*/) {\
00263   return operand1_printer(str);\
00264 }\
00265 inline String FormatForComparisonFailureMessage(\
00266     const operand2_type::value_type* str, const operand2_type& /*operand2*/) {\
00267   return operand1_printer(str);\
00268 }
00269 
00270 #if GTEST_HAS_STD_STRING
00271 GTEST_FORMAT_IMPL_(::std::string, String::ShowCStringQuoted)
00272 #endif  // GTEST_HAS_STD_STRING
00273 #if GTEST_HAS_STD_WSTRING
00274 GTEST_FORMAT_IMPL_(::std::wstring, String::ShowWideCStringQuoted)
00275 #endif  // GTEST_HAS_STD_WSTRING
00276 
00277 #if GTEST_HAS_GLOBAL_STRING
00278 GTEST_FORMAT_IMPL_(::string, String::ShowCStringQuoted)
00279 #endif  // GTEST_HAS_GLOBAL_STRING
00280 #if GTEST_HAS_GLOBAL_WSTRING
00281 GTEST_FORMAT_IMPL_(::wstring, String::ShowWideCStringQuoted)
00282 #endif  // GTEST_HAS_GLOBAL_WSTRING

00284 #undef GTEST_FORMAT_IMPL_

00286 // Constructs and returns the message for an equality assertion
00287 // (e.g. ASSERT_EQ, EXPECT_STREQ, etc) failure.
00288 //
00289 // The first four parameters are the expressions used in the assertion
00290 // and their values, as strings.  For example, for ASSERT_EQ(foo, bar)
00291 // where foo is 5 and bar is 6, we have:
00292 //
00293 //   expected_expression: "foo"
00294 //   actual_expression:   "bar"
00295 //   expected_value:      "5"
00296 //   actual_value:        "6"
00297 //
00298 // The ignoring_case parameter is true iff the assertion is a
00299 // *_STRCASEEQ*.  When it's true, the string " (ignoring case)" will
00300 // be inserted into the message.
00301 AssertionResult EqFailure(const char* expected_expression,
00302                           const char* actual_expression,
00303                           const String& expected_value,
00304                           const String& actual_value,
00305                           bool ignoring_case);
00306 
00307 
00308 // This template class represents an IEEE floating-point number
00309 // (either single-precision or double-precision, depending on the
00310 // template parameters).
00311 //
00312 // The purpose of this class is to do more sophisticated number
00313 // comparison.  (Due to round-off error, etc, it's very unlikely that
00314 // two floating-points will be equal exactly.  Hence a naive
00315 // comparison by the == operation often doesn't work.)
00316 //
00317 // Format of IEEE floating-point:
00318 //
00319 //   The most-significant bit being the leftmost, an IEEE
00320 //   floating-point looks like
00321 //
00322 //     sign_bit exponent_bits fraction_bits
00323 //
00324 //   Here, sign_bit is a single bit that designates the sign of the
00325 //   number.
00326 //
00327 //   For float, there are 8 exponent bits and 23 fraction bits.
00328 //
00329 //   For double, there are 11 exponent bits and 52 fraction bits.
00330 //
00331 //   More details can be found at
00332 //   http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IEEE_floating-point_standard.
00333 //
00334 // Template parameter:
00335 //
00336 //   RawType: the raw floating-point type (either float or double)
00337 template <typename RawType>
00338 class FloatingPoint {
00339  public:
00340   // Defines the unsigned integer type that has the same size as the
00341   // floating point number.
00342   typedef typename TypeWithSize<sizeof(RawType)>::UInt Bits;
00343 
00344   // Constants.
00345 
00346   // # of bits in a number.
00347   static const size_t kBitCount = 8*sizeof(RawType);
00348 
00349   // # of fraction bits in a number.
00350   static const size_t kFractionBitCount =
00351     std::numeric_limits<RawType>::digits - 1;
00352 
00353   // # of exponent bits in a number.
00354   static const size_t kExponentBitCount = kBitCount - 1 - kFractionBitCount;
00355 
00356   // The mask for the sign bit.
00357   static const Bits kSignBitMask = static_cast<Bits>(1) << (kBitCount - 1);
00358 
00359   // The mask for the fraction bits.
00360   static const Bits kFractionBitMask =
00361     ~static_cast<Bits>(0) >> (kExponentBitCount + 1);
00362 
00363   // The mask for the exponent bits.
00364   static const Bits kExponentBitMask = ~(kSignBitMask | kFractionBitMask);
00365 
00366   // How many ULP's (Units in the Last Place) we want to tolerate when
00367   // comparing two numbers.  The larger the value, the more error we
00368   // allow.  A 0 value means that two numbers must be exactly the same
00369   // to be considered equal.
00370   //
00371   // The maximum error of a single floating-point operation is 0.5
00372   // units in the last place.  On Intel CPU's, all floating-point
00373   // calculations are done with 80-bit precision, while double has 64
00374   // bits.  Therefore, 4 should be enough for ordinary use.
00375   //
00376   // See the following article for more details on ULP:
00377   // http://www.cygnus-software.com/papers/comparingfloats/comparingfloats.htm.
00378   static const size_t kMaxUlps = 4;
00379 
00380   // Constructs a FloatingPoint from a raw floating-point number.
00381   //
00382   // On an Intel CPU, passing a non-normalized NAN (Not a Number)
00383   // around may change its bits, although the new value is guaranteed
00384   // to be also a NAN.  Therefore, don't expect this constructor to
00385   // preserve the bits in x when x is a NAN.
00386   explicit FloatingPoint(const RawType& x) : value_(x) {}
00387 
00388   // Static methods
00389 
00390   // Reinterprets a bit pattern as a floating-point number.
00391   //
00392   // This function is needed to test the AlmostEquals() method.
00393   static RawType ReinterpretBits(const Bits bits) {
00394     FloatingPoint fp(0);
00395     fp.bits_ = bits;
00396     return fp.value_;
00397   }
00398 
00399   // Returns the floating-point number that represent positive infinity.
00400   static RawType Infinity() {
00401     return ReinterpretBits(kExponentBitMask);
00402   }
00403 
00404   // Non-static methods
00405 
00406   // Returns the bits that represents this number.
00407   const Bits &bits() const { return bits_; }
00408 
00409   // Returns the exponent bits of this number.
00410   Bits exponent_bits() const { return kExponentBitMask & bits_; }
00411 
00412   // Returns the fraction bits of this number.
00413   Bits fraction_bits() const { return kFractionBitMask & bits_; }
00414 
00415   // Returns the sign bit of this number.
00416   Bits sign_bit() const { return kSignBitMask & bits_; }
00417 
00418   // Returns true iff this is NAN (not a number).
00419   bool is_nan() const {
00420     // It's a NAN if the exponent bits are all ones and the fraction
00421     // bits are not entirely zeros.
00422     return (exponent_bits() == kExponentBitMask) && (fraction_bits() != 0);
00423   }
00424 
00425   // Returns true iff this number is at most kMaxUlps ULP's away from
00426   // rhs.  In particular, this function:
00427   //
00428   //   - returns false if either number is (or both are) NAN.
00429   //   - treats really large numbers as almost equal to infinity.
00430   //   - thinks +0.0 and -0.0 are 0 DLP's apart.
00431   bool AlmostEquals(const FloatingPoint& rhs) const {
00432     // The IEEE standard says that any comparison operation involving
00433     // a NAN must return false.
00434     if (is_nan() || rhs.is_nan()) return false;
00435 
00436     return DistanceBetweenSignAndMagnitudeNumbers(bits_, rhs.bits_) <= kMaxUlps;
00437   }
00438 
00439  private:
00440   // Converts an integer from the sign-and-magnitude representation to
00441   // the biased representation.  More precisely, let N be 2 to the
00442   // power of (kBitCount - 1), an integer x is represented by the
00443   // unsigned number x + N.
00444   //
00445   // For instance,
00446   //
00447   //   -N + 1 (the most negative number representable using
00448   //          sign-and-magnitude) is represented by 1;
00449   //   0      is represented by N; and
00450   //   N - 1  (the biggest number representable using
00451   //          sign-and-magnitude) is represented by 2N - 1.
00452   //
00453   // Read http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Signed_number_representations
00454   // for more details on signed number representations.
00455   static Bits SignAndMagnitudeToBiased(const Bits &sam) {
00456     if (kSignBitMask & sam) {
00457       // sam represents a negative number.
00458       return ~sam + 1;
00459     } else {
00460       // sam represents a positive number.
00461       return kSignBitMask | sam;
00462     }
00463   }
00464 
00465   // Given two numbers in the sign-and-magnitude representation,
00466   // returns the distance between them as an unsigned number.
00467   static Bits DistanceBetweenSignAndMagnitudeNumbers(const Bits &sam1,
00468                                                      const Bits &sam2) {
00469     const Bits biased1 = SignAndMagnitudeToBiased(sam1);
00470     const Bits biased2 = SignAndMagnitudeToBiased(sam2);
00471     return (biased1 >= biased2) ? (biased1 - biased2) : (biased2 - biased1);
00472   }
00473 
00474   union {
00475     RawType value_;  // The raw floating-point number.
00476     Bits bits_;      // The bits that represent the number.
00477   };
00478 };
00479 
00480 // Typedefs the instances of the FloatingPoint template class that we
00481 // care to use.
00482 typedef FloatingPoint<float> Float;
00483 typedef FloatingPoint<double> Double;
00484 
00485 // In order to catch the mistake of putting tests that use different
00486 // test fixture classes in the same test case, we need to assign
00487 // unique IDs to fixture classes and compare them.  The TypeId type is
00488 // used to hold such IDs.  The user should treat TypeId as an opaque
00489 // type: the only operation allowed on TypeId values is to compare
00490 // them for equality using the == operator.
00491 typedef const void* TypeId;
00492 
00493 template <typename T>
00494 class TypeIdHelper {
00495  public:
00496   // dummy_ must not have a const type.  Otherwise an overly eager
00497   // compiler (e.g. MSVC 7.1 & 8.0) may try to merge
00498   // TypeIdHelper<T>::dummy_ for different Ts as an "optimization".
00499   static bool dummy_;
00500 };
00501 
00502 template <typename T>
00503 bool TypeIdHelper<T>::dummy_ = false;
00504 
00505 // GetTypeId<T>() returns the ID of type T.  Different values will be
00506 // returned for different types.  Calling the function twice with the
00507 // same type argument is guaranteed to return the same ID.
00508 template <typename T>
00509 TypeId GetTypeId() {
00510   // The compiler is required to allocate a different
00511   // TypeIdHelper<T>::dummy_ variable for each T used to instantiate
00512   // the template.  Therefore, the address of dummy_ is guaranteed to
00513   // be unique.
00514   return &(TypeIdHelper<T>::dummy_);
00515 }
00516 
00517 // Returns the type ID of ::testing::Test.  Always call this instead
00518 // of GetTypeId< ::testing::Test>() to get the type ID of
00519 // ::testing::Test, as the latter may give the wrong result due to a
00520 // suspected linker bug when compiling Google Test as a Mac OS X
00521 // framework.
00522 TypeId GetTestTypeId();
00523 
00524 // Defines the abstract factory interface that creates instances
00525 // of a Test object.
00526 class TestFactoryBase {
00527  public:
00528   virtual ~TestFactoryBase() {}
00529 
00530   // Creates a test instance to run. The instance is both created and destroyed
00531   // within TestInfoImpl::Run()
00532   virtual Test* CreateTest() = 0;
00533 
00534  protected:
00535   TestFactoryBase() {}
00536 
00537  private:
00538   GTEST_DISALLOW_COPY_AND_ASSIGN_(TestFactoryBase);
00539 };
00540 
00541 // This class provides implementation of TeastFactoryBase interface.
00542 // It is used in TEST and TEST_F macros.
00543 template <class TestClass>
00544 class TestFactoryImpl : public TestFactoryBase {
00545  public:
00546   virtual Test* CreateTest() { return new TestClass; }
00547 };

00551 // Predicate-formatters for implementing the HRESULT checking macros
00552 // {ASSERT|EXPECT}_HRESULT_{SUCCEEDED|FAILED}
00553 // We pass a long instead of HRESULT to avoid causing an
00554 // include dependency for the HRESULT type.
00555 AssertionResult IsHRESULTSuccess(const char* expr, long hr);  // NOLINT

00560 // Formats a source file path and a line number as they would appear
00561 // in a compiler error message.
00562 inline String FormatFileLocation(const char* file, int line) {
00563   const char* const file_name = file == NULL ? "unknown file" : file;
00564   if (line < 0) {
00565     return String::Format("%s:", file_name);
00566   }
00567 #ifdef _MSC_VER
00568   return String::Format("%s(%d):", file_name, line);
00569 #else
00570   return String::Format("%s:%d:", file_name, line);
00571 #endif  // _MSC_VER
00572 }
00573 
00574 // Types of SetUpTestCase() and TearDownTestCase() functions.
00575 typedef void (*SetUpTestCaseFunc)();
00576 typedef void (*TearDownTestCaseFunc)();
00577 
00578 // Creates a new TestInfo object and registers it with Google Test;
00579 // returns the created object.
00580 //
00581 // Arguments:
00582 //
00583 //   test_case_name:   name of the test case
00584 //   name:             name of the test
00585 //   test_case_comment: a comment on the test case that will be included in
00586 //                      the test output
00587 //   comment:          a comment on the test that will be included in the
00588 //                     test output
00589 //   fixture_class_id: ID of the test fixture class
00590 //   set_up_tc:        pointer to the function that sets up the test case
00591 //   tear_down_tc:     pointer to the function that tears down the test case
00592 //   factory:          pointer to the factory that creates a test object.
00593 //                     The newly created TestInfo instance will assume
00594 //                     ownership of the factory object.
00595 TestInfo* MakeAndRegisterTestInfo(
00596     const char* test_case_name, const char* name,
00597     const char* test_case_comment, const char* comment,
00598     TypeId fixture_class_id,
00599     SetUpTestCaseFunc set_up_tc,
00600     TearDownTestCaseFunc tear_down_tc,
00601     TestFactoryBase* factory);
00602 
00603 #if defined(GTEST_HAS_TYPED_TEST) || defined(GTEST_HAS_TYPED_TEST_P)
00604 
00605 // State of the definition of a type-parameterized test case.
00606 class TypedTestCasePState {
00607  public:
00608   TypedTestCasePState() : registered_(false) {}
00609 
00610   // Adds the given test name to defined_test_names_ and return true
00611   // if the test case hasn't been registered; otherwise aborts the
00612   // program.
00613   bool AddTestName(const char* file, int line, const char* case_name,
00614                    const char* test_name) {
00615     if (registered_) {
00616       fprintf(stderr, "%s Test %s must be defined before "
00617               "REGISTER_TYPED_TEST_CASE_P(%s, ...).\n",
00618               FormatFileLocation(file, line).c_str(), test_name, case_name);
00619       abort();
00620     }
00621     defined_test_names_.insert(test_name);
00622     return true;
00623   }
00624 
00625   // Verifies that registered_tests match the test names in
00626   // defined_test_names_; returns registered_tests if successful, or
00627   // aborts the program otherwise.
00628   const char* VerifyRegisteredTestNames(
00629       const char* file, int line, const char* registered_tests);
00630 
00631  private:
00632   bool registered_;
00633   ::std::set<const char*> defined_test_names_;
00634 };
00635 
00636 // Skips to the first non-space char after the first comma in 'str';
00637 // returns NULL if no comma is found in 'str'.
00638 inline const char* SkipComma(const char* str) {
00639   const char* comma = strchr(str, ',');
00640   if (comma == NULL) {
00641     return NULL;
00642   }
00643   while (isspace(*(++comma))) {}
00644   return comma;
00645 }
00646 
00647 // Returns the prefix of 'str' before the first comma in it; returns
00648 // the entire string if it contains no comma.
00649 inline String GetPrefixUntilComma(const char* str) {
00650   const char* comma = strchr(str, ',');
00651   return comma == NULL ? String(str) : String(str, comma - str);
00652 }
00653 
00654 // TypeParameterizedTest<Fixture, TestSel, Types>::Register()
00655 // registers a list of type-parameterized tests with Google Test.  The
00656 // return value is insignificant - we just need to return something
00657 // such that we can call this function in a namespace scope.
00658 //
00659 // Implementation note: The GTEST_TEMPLATE_ macro declares a template
00660 // template parameter.  It's defined in gtest-type-util.h.
00661 template <GTEST_TEMPLATE_ Fixture, class TestSel, typename Types>
00662 class TypeParameterizedTest {
00663  public:
00664   // 'index' is the index of the test in the type list 'Types'
00665   // specified in INSTANTIATE_TYPED_TEST_CASE_P(Prefix, TestCase,
00666   // Types).  Valid values for 'index' are [0, N - 1] where N is the
00667   // length of Types.
00668   static bool Register(const char* prefix, const char* case_name,
00669                        const char* test_names, int index) {
00670     typedef typename Types::Head Type;
00671     typedef Fixture<Type> FixtureClass;
00672     typedef typename GTEST_BIND_(TestSel, Type) TestClass;
00673 
00674     // First, registers the first type-parameterized test in the type
00675     // list.
00676     MakeAndRegisterTestInfo(
00677         String::Format("%s%s%s/%d", prefix, prefix[0] == '\0' ? "" : "/",
00678                        case_name, index).c_str(),
00679         GetPrefixUntilComma(test_names).c_str(),
00680         String::Format("TypeParam = %s", GetTypeName<Type>().c_str()).c_str(),
00681         "",
00682         GetTypeId<FixtureClass>(),
00683         TestClass::SetUpTestCase,
00684         TestClass::TearDownTestCase,
00685         new TestFactoryImpl<TestClass>);
00686 
00687     // Next, recurses (at compile time) with the tail of the type list.
00688     return TypeParameterizedTest<Fixture, TestSel, typename Types::Tail>
00689         ::Register(prefix, case_name, test_names, index + 1);
00690   }
00691 };
00692 
00693 // The base case for the compile time recursion.
00694 template <GTEST_TEMPLATE_ Fixture, class TestSel>
00695 class TypeParameterizedTest<Fixture, TestSel, Types0> {
00696  public:
00697   static bool Register(const char* /*prefix*/, const char* /*case_name*/,
00698                        const char* /*test_names*/, int /*index*/) {
00699     return true;
00700   }
00701 };
00702 
00703 // TypeParameterizedTestCase<Fixture, Tests, Types>::Register()
00704 // registers *all combinations* of 'Tests' and 'Types' with Google
00705 // Test.  The return value is insignificant - we just need to return
00706 // something such that we can call this function in a namespace scope.
00707 template <GTEST_TEMPLATE_ Fixture, typename Tests, typename Types>
00708 class TypeParameterizedTestCase {
00709  public:
00710   static bool Register(const char* prefix, const char* case_name,
00711                        const char* test_names) {
00712     typedef typename Tests::Head Head;
00713 
00714     // First, register the first test in 'Test' for each type in 'Types'.
00715     TypeParameterizedTest<Fixture, Head, Types>::Register(
00716         prefix, case_name, test_names, 0);
00717 
00718     // Next, recurses (at compile time) with the tail of the test list.
00719     return TypeParameterizedTestCase<Fixture, typename Tests::Tail, Types>
00720         ::Register(prefix, case_name, SkipComma(test_names));
00721   }
00722 };
00723 
00724 // The base case for the compile time recursion.
00725 template <GTEST_TEMPLATE_ Fixture, typename Types>
00726 class TypeParameterizedTestCase<Fixture, Templates0, Types> {
00727  public:
00728   static bool Register(const char* prefix, const char* case_name,
00729                        const char* test_names) {
00730     return true;
00731   }
00732 };
00733 
00734 #endif  // GTEST_HAS_TYPED_TEST || GTEST_HAS_TYPED_TEST_P
00735 
00736 // Returns the current OS stack trace as a String.
00737 //
00738 // The maximum number of stack frames to be included is specified by
00739 // the gtest_stack_trace_depth flag.  The skip_count parameter
00740 // specifies the number of top frames to be skipped, which doesn't
00741 // count against the number of frames to be included.
00742 //
00743 // For example, if Foo() calls Bar(), which in turn calls
00744 // GetCurrentOsStackTraceExceptTop(..., 1), Foo() will be included in
00745 // the trace but Bar() and GetCurrentOsStackTraceExceptTop() won't.
00746 String GetCurrentOsStackTraceExceptTop(UnitTest* unit_test, int skip_count);
00747 
00748 // Returns the number of failed test parts in the given test result object.
00749 int GetFailedPartCount(const TestResult* result);
00750 
00751 }  // namespace internal
00752 }  // namespace testing
00753 
00754 #define GTEST_MESSAGE_(message, result_type) \
00755   ::testing::internal::AssertHelper(result_type, __FILE__, __LINE__, message) \
00756     = ::testing::Message()
00757 
00758 #define GTEST_FATAL_FAILURE_(message) \
00759   return GTEST_MESSAGE_(message, ::testing::TPRT_FATAL_FAILURE)
00760 
00761 #define GTEST_NONFATAL_FAILURE_(message) \
00762   GTEST_MESSAGE_(message, ::testing::TPRT_NONFATAL_FAILURE)
00763 
00764 #define GTEST_SUCCESS_(message) \
00765   GTEST_MESSAGE_(message, ::testing::TPRT_SUCCESS)
00766 
00767 #define GTEST_TEST_THROW_(statement, expected_exception, fail) \
00768   GTEST_AMBIGUOUS_ELSE_BLOCKER_ \
00769   if (const char* gtest_msg = "") { \
00770     bool gtest_caught_expected = false; \
00771     try { \
00772       statement; \
00773     } \
00774     catch (expected_exception const&) { \
00775       gtest_caught_expected = true; \
00776     } \
00777     catch (...) { \
00778       gtest_msg = "Expected: " #statement " throws an exception of type " \
00779                   #expected_exception ".\n  Actual: it throws a different " \
00780                   "type."; \
00781       goto GTEST_CONCAT_TOKEN_(gtest_label_testthrow_, __LINE__); \
00782     } \
00783     if (!gtest_caught_expected) { \
00784       gtest_msg = "Expected: " #statement " throws an exception of type " \
00785                   #expected_exception ".\n  Actual: it throws nothing."; \
00786       goto GTEST_CONCAT_TOKEN_(gtest_label_testthrow_, __LINE__); \
00787     } \
00788   } else \
00789     GTEST_CONCAT_TOKEN_(gtest_label_testthrow_, __LINE__): \
00790       fail(gtest_msg)
00791 
00792 #define GTEST_TEST_NO_THROW_(statement, fail) \
00793   GTEST_AMBIGUOUS_ELSE_BLOCKER_ \
00794   if (const char* gtest_msg = "") { \
00795     try { \
00796       statement; \
00797     } \
00798     catch (...) { \
00799       gtest_msg = "Expected: " #statement " doesn't throw an exception.\n" \
00800                   "  Actual: it throws."; \
00801       goto GTEST_CONCAT_TOKEN_(gtest_label_testnothrow_, __LINE__); \
00802     } \
00803   } else \
00804     GTEST_CONCAT_TOKEN_(gtest_label_testnothrow_, __LINE__): \
00805       fail(gtest_msg)
00806 
00807 #define GTEST_TEST_ANY_THROW_(statement, fail) \
00808   GTEST_AMBIGUOUS_ELSE_BLOCKER_ \
00809   if (const char* gtest_msg = "") { \
00810     bool gtest_caught_any = false; \
00811     try { \
00812       statement; \
00813     } \
00814     catch (...) { \
00815       gtest_caught_any = true; \
00816     } \
00817     if (!gtest_caught_any) { \
00818       gtest_msg = "Expected: " #statement " throws an exception.\n" \
00819                   "  Actual: it doesn't."; \
00820       goto GTEST_CONCAT_TOKEN_(gtest_label_testanythrow_, __LINE__); \
00821     } \
00822   } else \
00823     GTEST_CONCAT_TOKEN_(gtest_label_testanythrow_, __LINE__): \
00824       fail(gtest_msg)
00825 
00826 
00827 #define GTEST_TEST_BOOLEAN_(boolexpr, booltext, actual, expected, fail) \
00828   GTEST_AMBIGUOUS_ELSE_BLOCKER_ \
00829   if (boolexpr) \
00830     ; \
00831   else \
00832     fail("Value of: " booltext "\n  Actual: " #actual "\nExpected: " #expected)
00833 
00834 #define GTEST_TEST_NO_FATAL_FAILURE_(statement, fail) \
00835   GTEST_AMBIGUOUS_ELSE_BLOCKER_ \
00836   if (const char* gtest_msg = "") { \
00837     ::testing::internal::HasNewFatalFailureHelper gtest_fatal_failure_checker; \
00838     { statement; } \
00839     if (gtest_fatal_failure_checker.has_new_fatal_failure()) { \
00840       gtest_msg = "Expected: " #statement " doesn't generate new fatal " \
00841                   "failures in the current thread.\n" \
00842                   "  Actual: it does."; \
00843       goto GTEST_CONCAT_TOKEN_(gtest_label_testnofatal_, __LINE__); \
00844     } \
00845   } else \
00846     GTEST_CONCAT_TOKEN_(gtest_label_testnofatal_, __LINE__): \
00847       fail(gtest_msg)
00848 
00849 // Expands to the name of the class that implements the given test.
00850 #define GTEST_TEST_CLASS_NAME_(test_case_name, test_name) \
00851   test_case_name##_##test_name##_Test
00852 
00853 // Helper macro for defining tests.
00854 #define GTEST_TEST_(test_case_name, test_name, parent_class, parent_id)\
00855 class GTEST_TEST_CLASS_NAME_(test_case_name, test_name) : public parent_class {\
00856  public:\
00857   GTEST_TEST_CLASS_NAME_(test_case_name, test_name)() {}\
00858  private:\
00859   virtual void TestBody();\
00860   static ::testing::TestInfo* const test_info_;\
00861   GTEST_DISALLOW_COPY_AND_ASSIGN_(\
00862       GTEST_TEST_CLASS_NAME_(test_case_name, test_name));\
00863 };\
00864 \
00865 ::testing::TestInfo* const GTEST_TEST_CLASS_NAME_(test_case_name, test_name)\
00866   ::test_info_ =\
00867     ::testing::internal::MakeAndRegisterTestInfo(\
00868         #test_case_name, #test_name, "", "", \
00869         (parent_id), \
00870         parent_class::SetUpTestCase, \
00871         parent_class::TearDownTestCase, \
00872         new ::testing::internal::TestFactoryImpl<\
00873             GTEST_TEST_CLASS_NAME_(test_case_name, test_name)>);\
00874 void GTEST_TEST_CLASS_NAME_(test_case_name, test_name)::TestBody()
00875
